info.game_comments:
Mark Born game 3.
Missing Final Jeopardy! responses.

(1, 1).clue: In 1990 this news network won its 1st news Emmy, for coverage of events in Tiananmen Sq.

(2, 1).clue: The value of the item stolen determines whether this crime is petty or grand

(3, 1).clue: This word meaning fantastic or bizarre is from the Italian for "of a grotto"

(4, 1).clue: You'll find the schoolhouse Grandma Moses attended at the museum in Bennington in this state

(5, 1).clue: Like Raphael, this artist of "Potato Eaters" & a "Starry Night" was dead at age 37

(6, 1).clue: In 1981 this First Lady didn't say a word to Mrs. Reagan as they rode to the capitol for the swearing-in

(1, 2).clue: Peter Falk & Patrick McGoohan won Emmys for this series in 1975 & in 1990

(2, 2).clue: Sometimes called conciliation court, it's an informal court for settling small debts

(3, 2).clue: This adjective meaning tearful comes from the Latin word for tear, lacrima

(4, 2).clue: You can celebrate Oktoberfest in La Crosse & Bratwurst Days in Sheboygan in this state

(5, 2).clue: Giovanni da Bologna's 1564 sculpture of this god shows him with winged helmet & feet, running

(6, 2).clue: Mrs. Reagan says her husband has never discussed his divorce from this woman with anyone but her

(1, 3).clue: The mode in which the awards were telecast, or the FOX show that was named Best Variety Program

(2, 3).clue: From its start in 1789 to 1804, the U.S. Supreme Court consisted of judges from this party

(3, 3).clue: Panacea & panoply are 2 of the many words starting with "pan" that derive from this language

(4, 3).clue: The Arkansas, South Platte & Rio Grande rivers begin in this Rocky Mountain state

(5, 3).clue: Nan Wood Graham, who posed for this painting by her brother in 1930, died in 1990

(1, 4).clue: She took home an Emmy for her 1989 interview with Marlon Brando on CBS

(2, 4).clue: 1 of the 2 types of practicing lawyers in Britain

(3, 4).clue: Peau de soie is a dress fabric whose name is French for "skin of" this fabric

(4, 4).clue: Cibola County is in this state where the Seven Cities of Cibola were thought to be

(5, 4).clue: Many of the people portrayed in his "The Night Watch" paid 100 guilders to be included

(1, 5).clue: The 2 Brians who skated off with Emmys for their performances in "Carmen on Ice"

(2, 5).clue: This list of cases waiting to be heard is kept by the clerk of the court

(3, 5).clue: Meaning "of the city of Saluq", the name of the saluki dog comes from this language

(4, 5).clue: Longfellow called this city "Queen City of the West" & it has kept the title

(5, 5).clue: This surrealist described his home region, Catalonia, as "The Nose of the Earth"

(1, 1).clue: 20 years before Bismarck, Joseph von Radowitz tried to unify this country under Prussian leadership

(2, 1).clue: The Olivier Theatre opened in this city in 1976 with a production of "Tamburlaine the Great"

(3, 1).clue: In ill health, Alvah Roebuck sold out to this partner for $25,000 in 1895

(4, 1).clue: In the American rhyme, the number of the "Engine, Engine" "Running along the Chicago line"

(5, 1).clue: In 1946 this city on the Riviera held its first international film festival

(6, 1).clue: It took two to do the Cambio, La Puerta & Doble Corte variations of this Argentine dance

(1, 2).clue: It looks as if Hawaii's Kamehameha I, like Mark Twain, came in with this astral event

(2, 2).clue: With few exceptions, the classical drama of India is written in this language

(3, 2).clue: Since he joined Disney as chairman & chief executive, company profits have increased eightfold

(5, 2).clue: During the two world wars, the French gov't briefly moved to this city famous for its wines

(6, 2).clue: Marlene Raymond passed under a flaming bar 6 1/8 inches off the floor, a record for this dance

(1, 3).clue: 1 of the 2 nephews of Rua who jointly ruled the Huns after their uncle's death

(2, 3).clue: Arlecchino & Scapino were 2 of the Zanni, or Zanies, in this improvised Italian comedic form

(3, 3).clue: As the brains behind this co., Thomas J. Watson required "Think" signs in every corporate office

(4, 3).clue: It's what he says after "Teddy bear, teddy bear" turns out the light

(5, 3).clue: The nation's oldest major city, it's also the main seaport

(6, 3).clue: During a 1988 party in Miami, 119,986 people joined the longest line ever to do this dance

(1, 4).clue: The 2 UN secretaries-general who came from Scandinavia

(2, 4).clue: Many of Euripides' plays featured this theatrical device, "the god from the machine"

(3, 4).clue: Deciding the corporate life wasn't for him, he left Apple Computer & Steven Jobs behind in 1985

(4, 4).clue: The sparrow killed Cock Robin, but "Who saw him die? 'I', said" this creature

(5, 4).clue: A major battle of the revolution took place in this city, now famous for its grand prix

(6, 4).clue: Dance meaning "the latest thing" in Portuguese that Stan Getz took from Brazil to the U.S. in 1962

(1, 5).clue: She was a lady in waiting to Henry VIII's 1st & 2nd wives before becoming his 3rd wife

(2, 5).clue: Riots followed the opening of this Synge play at Dublin's Abbey Theatre

(3, 5).clue: This founder of K Mart remained chairman of the company until 1966, a month before his 99th birthday

(4, 5).clue: What "Nancy Etticoat in a white petticoat" who, "the longer she stands, the shorter she grows" really is

(5, 5).clue: A cooking style utilizing onions is named for this city at the juncture of the Rhone & Saone rivers

(6, 5).clue: A caller would lead this 1930s dance, not named for NYC's nickname, but a Columbia, S.C. nightclub

(0, 0).clue: Named for a U.S. president, this author wrote a 5-volume biography of that president in the 1850s
